metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: Git Commit
Change Platform:
What is a Commit?
A commit is like a save point in your project.
content.html: A commit is like a save point in your project.

content.text: It records a snapshot of your files at a certain time, with a message describing what changed.
content.html: It records a snapshot of your files at a certain time, with a message describing what changed.

content.text: You can always go back to a previous commit if you need to.
content.html: You can always go back to a previous commit if you need to.

content.text: Here are some key commands for commits:
content.html: Here are some key commands for commits:

content.text: How to Commit with a Message ( -m )
To save your staged changes, use git commit -m "your message" :
content.html: To save your staged changes, use git commit -m "your message":

content.code:
git
commit -m
"First release of Hello World!"

[master (root-commit) 221ec6e] First release of Hello World!
3 files changed, 26 insertions(+)
create mode 100644 README.md
create mode 100644 bluestyle.css
create mode 100644 index.html
content.code_html:
git commit -m "First release of Hello World!"
[master (root-commit) 221ec6e] First release of Hello World!
 3 files changed, 26 insertions(+)
 create mode 100644 README.md
 create mode 100644 bluestyle.css
 create mode 100644 index.html

content.text: Always write a clear message so you and others can understand what changed.
content.html: Always write a clear message so you and others can understand what changed.

content.text: Commit All Changes Without Staging ( -a )
You can skip the staging step for already tracked files with git commit -a -m "message" .
content.html: You can skip the staging step for already tracked files with git commit -a -m "message".

content.text: This commits all modified and deleted files, but not new/untracked files .
content.html: This commits all modified and deleted files, but not new/untracked files.

content.code:
git
commit -a -m
"Quick update to README"

[master 123abcd] Quick update to README
1 file changed, 2 insertions(+)
content.code_html:
git commit -a -m "Quick update to README"
[master 123abcd] Quick update to README
 1 file changed, 2 insertions(+)

content.text: Warning: Skipping the staging step can make you include unwanted changes. Use with care.
content.html: Warning: Skipping the staging step can make you include unwanted changes. Use with care.

content.text: Note: git commit -a does not work for new/untracked files. You must use git add < file > first for new files.
content.html: Note: git commit -a does not work for new/untracked files. You must use git add <file> first for new files.

content.code:
$
git
commit -a -m
"Try to commit new file"

On branch master

No commits yet

Untracked files:
(use "git add ..." to include in what will be committed)
index.html

nothing added to commit but untracked files present (use "git add" to track)
content.code_html:
$ git commit -a -m "Try to commit new file"
On branch master

No commits yet

Untracked files:
  (use "git add ..." to include in what will be committed)
        index.html

nothing added to commit but untracked files present (use "git add" to track)

content.text: Write Multi-line Commit Messages
If you just type git commit (no -m ), your default editor will open so you can write a detailed, multi-line message:
content.html: If you just type git commit (no -m), your default editor will open so you can write a detailed, multi-line message:

content.code_html: git commit

content.text: Write a short summary on the first line, leave a blank line, then add more details below.
content.html: Write a short summary on the first line, leave a blank line, then add more details below.

content.text: Commit Message Best Practices:
Other Useful Commit Options
View Commit History ( git log )
To view the history of commits for a repository, you can use the git log command:
content.html: To view the history of commits for a repository, you can use the git log command:

content.code:
git
log
commit 09f4acd3f8836b7f6fc44ad9e012f82faf861803 (HEAD -> master)
Author: w3schools-test

Date:   Fri Mar 26 09:35:54 2021 +0100

Updated index.html with a new line

commit 221ec6e10aeedbfd02b85264087cd9adc18e4b26
Author: w3schools-test

Date:   Fri Mar 26 09:13:07 2021 +0100

First release of Hello World!
content.code_html:
git log
commit 09f4acd3f8836b7f6fc44ad9e012f82faf861803 (HEAD -> master)
Author: w3schools-test 
Date:   Fri Mar 26 09:35:54 2021 +0100

    Updated index.html with a new line

commit 221ec6e10aeedbfd02b85264087cd9adc18e4b26
Author: w3schools-test 
Date:   Fri Mar 26 09:13:07 2021 +0100

    First release of Hello World!

content.text: For a shorter view, use git log --oneline :
content.html: For a shorter view, use git log --oneline:

content.code:
git
log --oneline
09f4acd Updated index.html with a new line
221ec6e First release of Hello World!
content.code_html:
git log --oneline
09f4acd Updated index.html with a new line
221ec6e First release of Hello World!

content.text: To see which files changed in each commit, use git log --stat :
content.html: To see which files changed in each commit, use git log --stat:

content.code_html: git log --stat
